to reporting class C.

The Annual Report for 2014 is presented in DKK.

The Financial Statements have been prepared under the historical cost method.
Revenues are recognised in the income statement as earned. Furthermore, value adjustments of financial assets
and liabilities measured at fair value or amortised cost are recognised. Moreover, all expenses incurred to
achieve the earnings for the year are recognised in the income statement, including depreciation, amortization,
impairment losses and provisions as well as reversals due to changed accounting estimates of amounts that
have previously been recognised in the income statement.
Assets are recognised in the balance sheet when it is probable that future economic benefits attributable to the
asset will flow to the Company, and the value of the asset can be measured reliably.
Liabilities are recognised in the balance sheet when it is probable that future economic benefits will flow out of
the Company, and the value of the liability can be measured reliably.
Assets and liabilities are initially measured at cost. Subsequently, assets and liabilities are measured as described
for each item below.
Danish kroner are used as the measurement currency. All other currencies are regarded as foreign currencies.
Translation policies
Transactions in foreign currencies are translated at the exchange rates at the dates of transaction. Gains and
losses arising due to differences between the transaction date rates and the rates at the dates of payment are
recognised in financial income and expenses in the income statement. Where foreign exchange transactions are
considered hedging of future cash flows, the value adjustments are recognised directly in equity.
Receivables, payables and other monetary items in foreign currencies that have not been settled at the balance
sheet date are translated at the exchange rates at the balance sheet date. Any differences between the exchange rates at the balance sheet date and the transaction date rates are recognised in financial income and expenses in
the income statement.
Fixed assets acquired in foreign currencies are measured at the transaction date rates.

Main activity
The purpose of the Company is to directly, or through holdings of shares in other companies, conduct technology
based business and other activities deemed by the Board to be associated with such business.
Development in the year
This income statement of the Company for 2014 shows a loss of DKK 685.102, and at 31 December 2014 the
balance sheet of the Company shows negative equity of DKK 1.234.417.
Steeper Energy has 2014 attracted interest from a large number of fibre resource owners, predominately from
forestry industry, as well as companies involved with petroleum energy. Many of these companies visited the
CBS plant in Aalborg and subsequently evaluated the Hydrofactionâ¢ process and tested the oil produced from
various feed-stocks. As a direct result of interaction with industry players, a 3 months test campaign, and a
third party engineering study of a commercial Hydrofactionâ¢ plant was paid by a global leader in the provision
of pulp, paper and forestry products. The development activities during the year have focused on furthering
our experience with the Companyâs Hydrofactionâ¢ technology including processing various feedstock
beyond forest residues, designing and installing new process solutions and honing operational protocols. Furthermore,
the Company progressed strategic partnerships with a number potential future licensees of Hydrofaction
â¢ as well as advanced commercialization activities toward the next stage of Hydrofactionâ¢ scale-up.
Development activities
The development project, âHydrofactionâ¢: From Low Value Raw Materials to a Valuable Synthetic Crude
Oilâ, was initiated in 2012 based on support from the Danish Energy Technology Development and Demonstration
Program (EUDP) with a grant of DKK 6.9 million, and a total budget of DKK 10.97 million and was
completed by the end of 2013. The final report was submitted and approved in March 2014.
The development project, âSulphur-Free Marine Fuel Produced from Woodâ which was initiated in November
2013 with Aalborg University as partner and a DKK 539k grant from the Danish Ministry of Science and
Innovation (under the so-called Knowledge Coupon Scheme) was completed in 2014.
Steeper Energy continues in its role within the âC3BO- Center for Biooilâ established at Aalborg University
by January 2014 with a DKK 21.8 grant from the Danish Strategic Research Council. The C3BO centre has
participation Aalborg University (DK), Aarhus University (DK), Paul Scherrer Institute (CH), NTHU (N),
Shell (DK) and Canmet Energy (CA). The grant to the company is DKK 750k of a total budget of DKK 2 million
over 4 years.
A new development project, âAdvancement of the Hydrofactionâ¢ Technology Projectâ, was granted by the
Danish Energy Technology Development and Demonstration Program (EUDP) with a main goal to mature the
technology to commercial realization through continued testing and development activities using CBS plant.
The project includes a significant upgrade of the existing plant at Aalborg University including increasing its
throughput capacity. The grant totals DKK 17.3 million against a total budgeted cost of DKK 29.5 million. The
project was initiated by July 1st, 2014 and will be executed in cooperation with Aalborg University over a
three-year period. Steeper Energyâs share of the grant amounts to DKK 9.16 million.
In December 2014, the European Commission notified Steeper Energy that the project âResource and Energy
Efficient Conversion of Biomass-to-Hydrocarbon oilâ was shortlisted for a prestigious MEUR 1.848 grant
from its Horizon 2020 SME-Phase 2 program. The Company confirmed the grant in early 2015. The main
objectives of the project is to finalize project siting and other development issues including closing on the strategic
funding partner(s) for a two orders-of-magnitude scale-up as compared to the existing CBS plant or a
5.000 metric ton per annum name-plate export module as well as to develop specific business cases, together
with commercial partners, for the sale of the HydrofactionTM Oil, including: a low-sulfur diesel fuel for the
marine sector or as a renewable fuel oil for co-processing in petroleum refineries for the production of diesel or
jet fuels. The project also aims to identify and mitigate risks associated with technical, economical and financial
aspects of commercialization and is executed to be executed over a two year timeframe starting from April
2015.
Financing
The Company and its independent sister company Steeper Energy Canada Limited have since 2012 obtained
initial funding in the form of convertible loans from a Canadian private equity group. In 2014 this group has
given additional loans so that by 31 December 2014 the total funding including accrued interest amounts to
CAD 4,187k. Of this, CAD 2,689k has been borrowed by Steeper Energy ApS, with the remainder utilized by
the Steeper Energy Canada Ltd. The two entities are jointly and severally liable for the total loan capital. It is
expected that the loan will be converted into to equity midway through 2015.
Intellectual Property Rights â Patenting
As a technology-based enterprise the Company finds it critical to protect critical elements of its technology and
knowledge through patenting. At the beginning of the year the Company had 46 active patent applications
divided into 12 patent families. Two patent families were continued as international PCT applications in 2014.
In addition, a new priority application was filed and one was discontinued. Thus, by the end of 2014, the Company
had 46 patent applications in 12 patent families.
Commercialization
The operation of the CBS plant over the past 24 months and the quality of the Hydrofactionâ¢ oil that is produced
has attracted interest from a large number of multinational companies who are investigating opportunities
to enter the development and provision of Advanced Biofuels (second generation biofuels). These companies have a common opportunity: declining markets for their primary products and a desire to monetize excess
low-value or waste resources such as forestry residuals, timber processing wastes, pulp & paper co-products,
agricultural residues or energy crops. Many of these companies have visited the plant, and the company has an
ongoing dialogue with a number of these resource owners and energy organizations. As a direct result a paid 3-
month test campaign and funded a third party engineering study for a 2000 bpd or 100.000 fuel tonne export
plant that was completed in 2014.
Steeper Energy and its Canadian sister company Steeper Energy Canada Limited, has more than a dozen commercial
projects in Europe and Canada identified and in the early phases of the project development. The critical
step for market acceptance of Hydrofactionâ¢, and thus its commercialization, is the establishment of a
project of an industrial-scale demonstration project The objective of the industrial scale demonstration project
is to demonstrate technological and operational protocols at or near commercial-scale and substantially reduce
risks associated with scaling up to 2.000+ bpd commercial-scale projects and thereby, pave the way for thirdparty
investment and financing for future projects utilizing the Companyâs Hydrofactionâ¢ technology platform.
In the light of the significant milestones achieved and the Companyâs positioning for the future the result of the
activities in 2014 is considered to be excellent.
Subsequent events
The Companyâs first patent application âCoreâ was issued in the first jurisdiction (Canada) in April 2015.
No other events materially affecting the assessment of the Annual Report have occurred after the balance sheet
date.

Main activity
The purpose of the Company is to directly, or through holdings of shares in other companies, conduct technology
based business and other activities deemed by the Board to be associated with such business.
Development in the year
This income statement of the Company for 2014 shows a loss of DKK 685.102, and at 31 December 2014 the
balance sheet of the Company shows negative equity of DKK 1.234.417.
Steeper Energy has 2014 attracted interest from a large number of fibre resource owners, predominately from
forestry industry, as well as companies involved with petroleum energy. Many of these companies visited the
CBS plant in Aalborg and subsequently evaluated the Hydrofactionâ¢ process and tested the oil produced from
various feed-stocks. As a direct result of interaction with industry players, a 3 months test campaign, and a
third party engineering study of a commercial Hydrofactionâ¢ plant was paid by a global leader in the provision
of pulp, paper and forestry products. The development activities during the year have focused on furthering
our experience with the Companyâs Hydrofactionâ¢ technology including processing various feedstock
beyond forest residues, designing and installing new process solutions and honing operational protocols. Furthermore,
the Company progressed strategic partnerships with a number potential future licensees of Hydrofaction
â¢ as well as advanced commercialization activities toward the next stage of Hydrofactionâ¢ scale-up.
Development activities
The development project, âHydrofactionâ¢: From Low Value Raw Materials to a Valuable Synthetic Crude
Oilâ, was initiated in 2012 based on support from the Danish Energy Technology Development and Demonstration
Program (EUDP) with a grant of DKK 6.9 million, and a total budget of DKK 10.97 million and was
completed by the end of 2013. The final report was submitted and approved in March 2014.
The development project, âSulphur-Free Marine Fuel Produced from Woodâ which was initiated in November
2013 with Aalborg University as partner and a DKK 539k grant from the Danish Ministry of Science and
Innovation (under the so-called Knowledge Coupon Scheme) was completed in 2014.
Steeper Energy continues in its role within the âC3BO- Center for Biooilâ established at Aalborg University
by January 2014 with a DKK 21.8 grant from the Danish Strategic Research Council. The C3BO centre has
participation Aalborg University (DK), Aarhus University (DK), Paul Scherrer Institute (CH), NTHU (N),
Shell (DK) and Canmet Energy (CA). The grant to the company is DKK 750k of a total budget of DKK 2 million
over 4 years.
A new development project, âAdvancement of the Hydrofactionâ¢ Technology Projectâ, was granted by the
Danish Energy Technology Development and Demonstration Program (EUDP) with a main goal to mature the
technology to commercial realization through continued testing and development activities using CBS plant.
The project includes a significant upgrade of the existing plant at Aalborg University including increasing its
throughput capacity. The grant totals DKK 17.3 million against a total budgeted cost of DKK 29.5 million. The
project was initiated by July 1st, 2014 and will be executed in cooperation with Aalborg University over a
three-year period. Steeper Energyâs share of the grant amounts to DKK 9.16 million.
In December 2014, the European Commission notified Steeper Energy that the project âResource and Energy
Efficient Conversion of Biomass-to-Hydrocarbon oilâ was shortlisted for a prestigious MEUR 1.848 grant
from its Horizon 2020 SME-Phase 2 program. The Company confirmed the grant in early 2015. The main
objectives of the project is to finalize project siting and other development issues including closing on the strategic
funding partner(s) for a two orders-of-magnitude scale-up as compared to the existing CBS plant or a
5.000 metric ton per annum name-plate export module as well as to develop specific business cases, together
with commercial partners, for the sale of the HydrofactionTM Oil, including: a low-sulfur diesel fuel for the
marine sector or as a renewable fuel oil for co-processing in petroleum refineries for the production of diesel or
jet fuels. The project also aims to identify and mitigate risks associated with technical, economical and financial
aspects of commercialization and is executed to be executed over a two year timeframe starting from April
2015.
Financing
The Company and its independent sister company Steeper Energy Canada Limited have since 2012 obtained
initial funding in the form of convertible loans from a Canadian private equity group. In 2014 this group has
given additional loans so that by 31 December 2014 the total funding including accrued interest amounts to
CAD 4,187k. Of this, CAD 2,689k has been borrowed by Steeper Energy ApS, with the remainder utilized by
the Steeper Energy Canada Ltd. The two entities are jointly and severally liable for the total loan capital. It is
expected that the loan will be converted into to equity midway through 2015.
Intellectual Property Rights â Patenting
As a technology-based enterprise the Company finds it critical to protect critical elements of its technology and
knowledge through patenting. At the beginning of the year the Company had 46 active patent applications
divided into 12 patent families. Two patent families were continued as international PCT applications in 2014.
In addition, a new priority application was filed and one was discontinued. Thus, by the end of 2014, the Company
had 46 patent applications in 12 patent families.
Commercialization
The operation of the CBS plant over the past 24 months and the quality of the Hydrofactionâ¢ oil that is produced
has attracted interest from a large number of multinational companies who are investigating opportunities
to enter the development and provision of Advanced Biofuels (second generation biofuels). These companies have a common opportunity: declining markets for their primary products and a desire to monetize excess
low-value or waste resources such as forestry residuals, timber processing wastes, pulp & paper co-products,
agricultural residues or energy crops. Many of these companies have visited the plant, and the company has an
ongoing dialogue with a number of these resource owners and energy organizations. As a direct result a paid 3-
month test campaign and funded a third party engineering study for a 2000 bpd or 100.000 fuel tonne export
plant that was completed in 2014.
Steeper Energy and its Canadian sister company Steeper Energy Canada Limited, has more than a dozen commercial
projects in Europe and Canada identified and in the early phases of the project development. The critical
step for market acceptance of Hydrofactionâ¢, and thus its commercialization, is the establishment of a
project of an industrial-scale demonstration project The objective of the industrial scale demonstration project
is to demonstrate technological and operational protocols at or near commercial-scale and substantially reduce
risks associated with scaling up to 2.000+ bpd commercial-scale projects and thereby, pave the way for thirdparty
investment and financing for future projects utilizing the Companyâs Hydrofactionâ¢ technology platform.
In the light of the significant milestones achieved and the Companyâs positioning for the future the result of the
activities in 2014 is considered to be excellent.
Subsequent events
The Companyâs first patent application âCoreâ was issued in the first jurisdiction (Canada) in April 2015.
No other events materially affecting the assessment of the Annual Report have occurred after the balance sheet
date.

Main activity
The purpose of the Company is to directly, or through holdings of shares in other companies, conduct technology
based business and other activities deemed by the Board to be associated with such business.
Development in the year
This income statement of the Company for 2014 shows a loss of DKK 685.102, and at 31 December 2014 the
balance sheet of the Company shows negative equity of DKK 1.234.417.
Steeper Energy has 2014 attracted interest from a large number of fibre resource owners, predominately from
forestry industry, as well as companies involved with petroleum energy. Many of these companies visited the
CBS plant in Aalborg and subsequently evaluated the Hydrofactionâ¢ process and tested the oil produced from
various feed-stocks. As a direct result of interaction with industry players, a 3 months test campaign, and a
third party engineering study of a commercial Hydrofactionâ¢ plant was paid by a global leader in the provision
of pulp, paper and forestry products. The development activities during the year have focused on furthering
our experience with the Companyâs Hydrofactionâ¢ technology including processing various feedstock
beyond forest residues, designing and installing new process solutions and honing operational protocols. Furthermore,
the Company progressed strategic partnerships with a number potential future licensees of Hydrofaction
â¢ as well as advanced commercialization activities toward the next stage of Hydrofactionâ¢ scale-up.
Development activities
The development project, âHydrofactionâ¢: From Low Value Raw Materials to a Valuable Synthetic Crude
Oilâ, was initiated in 2012 based on support from the Danish Energy Technology Development and Demonstration
Program (EUDP) with a grant of DKK 6.9 million, and a total budget of DKK 10.97 million and was
completed by the end of 2013. The final report was submitted and approved in March 2014.
The development project, âSulphur-Free Marine Fuel Produced from Woodâ which was initiated in November
2013 with Aalborg University as partner and a DKK 539k grant from the Danish Ministry of Science and
Innovation (under the so-called Knowledge Coupon Scheme) was completed in 2014.
Steeper Energy continues in its role within the âC3BO- Center for Biooilâ established at Aalborg University
by January 2014 with a DKK 21.8 grant from the Danish Strategic Research Council. The C3BO centre has
participation Aalborg University (DK), Aarhus University (DK), Paul Scherrer Institute (CH), NTHU (N),
Shell (DK) and Canmet Energy (CA). The grant to the company is DKK 750k of a total budget of DKK 2 million
over 4 years.

Danish Energy Technology Development and Demonstration Program (EUDP) with a main goal to mature the
technology to commercial realization through continued testing and development activities using CBS plant.
The project includes a significant upgrade of the existing plant at Aalborg University including increasing its
throughput capacity. The grant totals DKK 17.3 million against a total budgeted cost of DKK 29.5 million. The
project was initiated by July 1st, 2014 and will be executed in cooperation with Aalborg University over a
three-year period. Steeper Energyâs share of the grant amounts to DKK 9.16 million.

Efficient Conversion of Biomass-to-Hydrocarbon oilâ was shortlisted for a prestigious MEUR 1.848 grant
from its Horizon 2020 SME-Phase 2 program. The Company confirmed the grant in early 2015. The main
objectives of the project is to finalize project siting and other development issues including closing on the strategic
funding partner(s) for a two orders-of-magnitude scale-up as compared to the existing CBS plant or a
5.000 metric ton per annum name-plate export module as well as to develop specific business cases, together
with commercial partners, for the sale of the HydrofactionTM Oil, including: a low-sulfur diesel fuel for the
marine sector or as a renewable fuel oil for co-processing in petroleum refineries for the production of diesel or
jet fuels. The project also aims to identify and mitigate risks associated with technical, economical and financial
aspects of commercialization and is executed to be executed over a two year timeframe starting from April
2015.

initial funding in the form of convertible loans from a Canadian private equity group. In 2014 this group has
given additional loans so that by 31 December 2014 the total funding including accrued interest amounts to
CAD 4,187k. Of this, CAD 2,689k has been borrowed by Steeper Energy ApS, with the remainder utilized by
the Steeper Energy Canada Ltd. The two entities are jointly and severally liable for the total loan capital. It is
expected that the loan will be converted into to equity midway through 2015.
Intellectual Property Rights â Patenting

knowledge through patenting. At the beginning of the year the Company had 46 active patent applications
divided into 12 patent families. Two patent families were continued as international PCT applications in 2014.
In addition, a new priority application was filed and one was discontinued. Thus, by the end of 2014, the Company
had 46 patent applications in 12 patent families.
Commercialization
The operation of the CBS plant over the past 24 months and the quality of the Hydrofactionâ¢ oil that is produced
has attracted interest from a large number of multinational companies who are investigating opportunities
to enter the development and provision of Advanced Biofuels (second generation biofuels). These companies have a common opportunity: declining markets for their primary products and a desire to monetize excess
low-value or waste resources such as forestry residuals, timber processing wastes, pulp & paper co-products,
agricultural residues or energy crops. Many of these companies have visited the plant, and the company has an
ongoing dialogue with a number of these resource owners and energy organizations. As a direct result a paid 3-
month test campaign and funded a third party engineering study for a 2000 bpd or 100.000 fuel tonne export
plant that was completed in 2014.
Steeper Energy and its Canadian sister company Steeper Energy Canada Limited, has more than a dozen commercial
projects in Europe and Canada identified and in the early phases of the project development. The critical
step for market acceptance of Hydrofactionâ¢, and thus its commercialization, is the establishment of a
project of an industrial-scale demonstration project The objective of the industrial scale demonstration project
is to demonstrate technological and operational protocols at or near commercial-scale and substantially reduce
risks associated with scaling up to 2.000+ bpd commercial-scale projects and thereby, pave the way for thirdparty
investment and financing for future projects utilizing the Companyâs Hydrofactionâ¢ technology platform.
In the light of the significant milestones achieved and the Companyâs positioning for the future the result of the
activities in 2014 is considered to be excellent.
Subsequent events
The Companyâs first patent application âCoreâ was issued in the first jurisdiction (Canada) in April 2015.
No other events materially affecting the assessment of the Annual Report have occurred after the balance sheet
date.

completed by the end of 2013. The final report was submitted and approved in March 2014.

forestry industry, as well as companies involved with petroleum energy. Many of these companies visited the
CBS plant in Aalborg and subsequently evaluated the Hydrofactionâ¢ process and tested the oil produced from
various feed-stocks. As a direct result of interaction with industry players, a 3 months test campaign, and a
third party engineering study of a commercial Hydrofactionâ¢ plant was paid by a global leader in the provision
of pulp, paper and forestry products. The development activities during the year have focused on furthering
our experience with the Companyâs Hydrofactionâ¢ technology including processing various feedstock
beyond forest residues, designing and installing new process solutions and honing operational protocols. Furthermore,
the Company progressed strategic partnerships with a number potential future licensees of Hydrofaction
â¢ as well as advanced commercialization activities toward the next stage of Hydrofactionâ¢ scale-up.
Development activities

Oilâ, was initiated in 2012 based on support from the Danish Energy Technology Development and Demonstration

participation Aalborg University (DK), Aarhus University (DK), Paul Scherrer Institute (CH), NTHU (N),
Shell (DK) and Canmet Energy (CA). The grant to the company is DKK 750k of a total budget of DKK 2 million

technology to commercial realization through continued testing and development activities using CBS plant.

activities in 2014 is considered to be excellent.

date.

to determine whether there is any indication of impairment other than that expressed by amortisation and depreciation.

corresponds to nominal value less provisions for bad debts. Provisions for bad debts are determined on the
basis of an individual assessment of each receivable, and in respect of trade receivables, a general provision is
also made based on the Companyâs experience from previous years.

Equity
Dividend
Dividend distribution proposed by Management for the year is disclosed as a separate equity item.
Deferred tax assets and liabilities
Deferred income tax is measured using the balance sheet liability method in respect of temporary differences
arising between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their carrying amounts for financial reporting purposes
on the basis of the intended use of the asset and settlement of the liability, respectively.
Deferred tax assets, including the tax base of tax loss carry-forwards, are measured at the value at which the
asset is expected to be realized, either by elimination in tax on future earnings or by set-off against deferred tax
liabilities within the same legal tax entity.

the balance sheet date when the deferred tax is expected to crystallise as current tax. Any changes in deferred
tax due to changes to tax rates are recognised in the income statement.

the year adjusted for tax on taxable incomes for prior years and tax paid on account. Extra payments and repayment
under the on account taxation scheme are recognised in the income statement in financial income and
expense.

Fixed-interest loans are recognised initially at the proceeds received net of transaction expenses incurred. Subsequently,
the loans are measured at amortised cost; the difference between the proceeds and the nominal value
is recognised as an interest expense in the income statement over the loan period.

column30:
Basis of Preparation
The Annual Report of Steeper Energy ApS for 2014 has been prepared in accordance with the provisions of
the Danish Financial Statements Act applying to enterprises of reporting class B as well as selected rules applying
to reporting class C.
The accounting policies applied remain unchanged from last year.
The Annual Report for 2014 is presented in DKK.
Recognition and measurement
The Financial Statements have been prepared under the historical cost method.
Revenues are recognised in the income statement as earned. Furthermore, value adjustments of financial assets
and liabilities measured at fair value or amortised cost are recognised. Moreover, all expenses incurred to
achieve the earnings for the year are recognised in the income statement, including depreciation, amortization,
impairment losses and provisions as well as reversals due to changed accounting estimates of amounts that
have previously been recognised in the income statement.
Assets are recognised in the balance sheet when it is probable that future economic benefits attributable to the
asset will flow to the Company, and the value of the asset can be measured reliably.
Liabilities are recognised in the balance sheet when it is probable that future economic benefits will flow out of
the Company, and the value of the liability can be measured reliably.
Assets and liabilities are initially measured at cost. Subsequently, assets and liabilities are measured as described
for each item below.
Danish kroner are used as the measurement currency. All other currencies are regarded as foreign currencies.
Translation policies
Transactions in foreign currencies are translated at the exchange rates at the dates of transaction. Gains and
losses arising due to differences between the transaction date rates and the rates at the dates of payment are
recognised in financial income and expenses in the income statement. Where foreign exchange transactions are
considered hedging of future cash flows, the value adjustments are recognised directly in equity.
Receivables, payables and other monetary items in foreign currencies that have not been settled at the balance
sheet date are translated at the exchange rates at the balance sheet date. Any differences between the exchange rates at the balance sheet date and the transaction date rates are recognised in financial income and expenses in
the income statement.
Fixed assets acquired in foreign currencies are measured at the transaction date rates.
